newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish building materials firm CRH buys Tilcon.
newsitem.headline: Irish building materials firm CRH buys Tilcon.

text.p: CRH Plc said Wednesday it was buying U.S. construction materials company Tilcon from British conglomerate BTR Plc for $332 million in the largest acquisition deal in its history.
The Irish building materials firm said it would dispose of some parts of Tilcon and the effective cost of the acquisition would be about $254 million.

"At an effective net cost to us of $254 million we have exceptional value, superb quarries and a most amazing fit with our present operations with pretty unique synergies," CRH Chief Executive Don Godson said in an interview.
Tilcon, one of the largest construction materials firms in the northeastern United States, would combine with CRH's U.S. operations to create "an unassailable position in the northeast," Godson said.
BTR sold Tilcon as part of a major strategic overhaul involving the sale of non-core businesses.
"We had a situation where we had quite a motivated seller working to a different agenda, and we were a dispassionate and patient negotiator," Godson said. "We got excellent value."

CRH announced the acquisition at the same time as reporting its half-year results. Pre-tax profits were 64.1 million punts ($103.6 million) in the first six months of 1996, 13 percent up on the same period the previous year.
"Increases in underlying profits in Ireland and the U.S. together with contributions from recent acquisitions were partly offset by declines in the UK and mainland Europe," Godson said.
He said the outlook for the rest of the year was generally positive, with Ireland and North America continuing to perform strongly.
Godson said CRH's policy of actively seeking smaller acquisitions would continue, helped by a stock offering that will raise a net 101 million punts ($164 million).
"Our acquisition policy has been the secret of our success, and we'll keep following it," Godson said.
